The best dash cam happens to be also an action cam and that is the insta360 AcePro 2.  It supports 8K recording at 30fps. At 4K at 30fps/60fps will record with HDR and PureView for night driving with incredible clarity.  The action cam has a dash cam setting that can also loop record you set the timer. It blows out of the dash cams in this video out of the water, as it also had a two chips one being a dedicated AI chip that makes sure your images are the best. Another BIG plus is has ultra wide mode with a wide angle of 157 degrees, it easily catches my side mirrors. The Ace Pro 2 by insta360 is the one to get. With a suction cup you stick it to your windshield clamp it auto horizons and when turned upside down for mounting it will record right side up and show the menu options accordingly.  The great thing about the AP2 is that it‚Äôs just simply amazing you can capture star trails, do timeshifts and time lapses when driving with absolute clarity.  The ultra wide screen does not distort the edges it is really that good. Many of us on the FB Ace Pro 2 forum page use it for dash cams especially motorcycles. Get it and you won‚Äôt be disappointed for dash cams it‚Äôs the KING by a long shot not cheap but worth every single penny and they always have great sales. You can also plug directly into your cigarette lighter for more connected with a USB-C cord so you can record AND charge the battery at the same time!

Some context: The cameras with starvis sensor will automatically win these tests most of the time. From Linus's video: the starting price is around 90 bucks. As we've seen with some of the sub-90 cams here, don't even think about it.
Great video! Every review I have seen has the Viofo on top. I recently bought one and it works well. You can get them with 1, 2, or 3 cameras (third is for interior).
No matter the cam you decide upon, make sure you get an SD card that uses SLC or MLC. These are often labeled as "Industrial", "Surveillance", High Endurance", etcetera... Secondly, get the highest capacity card your cam can support. Partition the card with about 10-20% of the capacity at the end as unallocated; format it to whatever filesystem your cam supports (I like to set the cluster size to 16-32k at anything over 32GB). The reason for going with the higher capacity cards is that it will take longer to hit the maximum times the card can be written to; this is when the nanoscopic transistors (basically tiny switches) wear out and can no longer flip. Having the additional unallocated space at the end gives the card's self-maintaining program (TRIM, GC, etc), if any, more free space to work with (over simplified).
I'm in the market for a new dashcam and your video was a big help to me. As usual,  your videos are thorough and provide a huge amount of great information.

Note that a dash cam with 24hour mode requires you to connect directly to your car battery. It has a fuse but it technically bypasses the car electrical safety. Keep in mind that it could void your car warranty. It could also drain the car battery more quickly if you don't use your car every day.

Thank you for this review, I bought the Viofo a couple of days ago from your link due to the review you did!  Great info...  I am an Engineer and this is exactly how I think about things, so your videos are super helpful for trusting I am getting what I want.  - Resolution: 2560√ó1440 @ 60fps (sharp + smooth). (30 FPS is better for night, but 60 FPS is best overall) - Bitrate: High (clear plates, less blockiness) - Format: TS (safer if power loss; convert to MP4 later) - Frequency: 60Hz (prevents light flicker in US). (IN Europe the electricity is 50 HZ, so choose that there) - Exposure: ‚Äì0.3 EV (balanced; prevents overexposure) (0 if you drive mainly at night) - HDR: Timer 7PM‚Äì7AM (off day, on at night) (helps with night glare in cities being on, but is worse for day, so timer is the way to go) - G-Sensor: Low (avoids false event locks) - Parking Mode: Auto Event Detection (if hardwired) - Stamp: Date/Time + GPS coords

I have been into dashcams for over a decade, many of the brands here i have never even heard of before, and there are hundreds of such brands that will launch a camera and then run so no service and no support. Today. You want system with starvis 2 sensor ( IMX 675 for 1440p and IMX 678 for 4K ) You also want HDR support for optimal chance of a plate capture in low light You also want to check the qualified memory card list, and you do not want to buy a too s¬¥malle one, IMHO today 1 channel or more, at least get a 256 GB memory card.  Be advised there is fake 4K systems out there, now they will output 4K footage but it is extrapolated up from a lesser 1080 or 1440p sensor and so do NOT have 4K detail levels.  If you feel like getting a bit smarter before pulling out the wallet, well come on over to dashcamtalk forum and hit up the search button  Finally Americans with their silly small licence plates and often just one in the rear, well you do NOT want to skimp on resolution, and especially on the rear camera that will the only chance of a oncoming car plate as it have passed by. Be careful comparing to plate capture we EURO boys can dish out, our plates are much larger and actually made for easy reading so no BS background graphics allowed here.
I have the Wolfbox mirror model. Got it mainly for rear camera for viewing trailer hookup. From new it resets all of your settings including screen, time, GPS everytime you start the car. I recently upgraded from the Viofo to the 70mai A810, because my main issue with the Viofo is the compression engine seems to blur/ghost frames, which becomes an issue at high speed. The camera is extraordinary for the price in every category but motion blur. I have the 70mai A500 in my other car and while the Viofo is debatably superior in some categories, like sharpness and HDR (especially headlight bloom and lit signs at night) it doesn‚Äôt experience the compression issues the Viofo has. Unsurprisingly, neither does the 70mai A810. It‚Äôs a more expensive camera but is superior or equal to the Viofo, offering a 4k sensor (I record at  1080p 60fps hdr off so high speed objects are sharp, and night recording is still adequate)  I moved the Viofo to the rear as a stand alone camera hardwired to the 12v accessory port in the trunk that is live only when the car is on. Easy cheap solution to a front and rear camera: just buy two.

One thing to keep in mind and not mentioned in this test.  Most of the bottom tier no-name brands are using the same chipsets for image processing. You will hear the same chime when starting up. That chipset really limits what the camera is capable of delivering. Bad chipset and an amazing 4k camera will yield a bad image. The upper and most mid tier brands (Viofo, Wolfbox, Rove, Yi, Blackvue, Thinkware, etc) usually will have custom or upgraded chipsets that deliver better quality images. The dashcamtalk forum is a great place for more info such as optimal settings. Something that wasn't done in this test.  The bottom tier is good enough if you just want to prove whether a light was green/red, brake checks, insurance fraud (backing up into your car) and poor driving in general. Upgrade to mid tier if you want to see the plate (real or fake) of the car that hit you and drove away. Upgrade to upper tier if you want to submit a clear video clip to the various youtube channels.
This is awesome. Looking forward to this after Linus's video 2 years ago basically shaming the entire industry.

Is there a way you could modify this test to include a reliability metric? That is, given "x" amount of force striking a car, how many failures to record per 100 strikes (or similar number) does the unit have? The best cam in the world is useless if it doesn't reliably activate when you need it to and nearly all models have failures at inopportune times.

Great content!  I have had a Viofo A119 V3 since 2023  with GPS and polarizing lens.  I installed a CLASS 10 mico SD card to keep from losing critical data. Class 10 has the ability to record data quickly and is very durable for read/write.  Kingston makes an affordable one. I have the Viofo set to continuously record and overwrite the oldest.  You can either set the camera to automatically save a video if a crash happens or set it up for manual saving by pressing a button. I need to experiment again with the auto save, previously, the camera was triggering when I went over railroad tracks or potholes. My only complaint is that the screen is VERY small. I have it mounted near the center roofline of my RAM truck which puts it more than an arms length away, making any viewing of menus or content nearly impossible from the drivers seat. Truck driver here.  Been using ROVE‚Äôs for a while with the 256gb cards so I can record a full day no loops in case I cannot download any feed quickly due to the issue of getting off the road with 80k lbs of a hazmat rig.  I would say if you have the money get whatever is going to give you the most frames per second because that‚Äôs really the only way to capture tag numbers when you‚Äôre rolling down the highway at 60 to 70 mph. Other than that, you‚Äôre gonna have to spend hundreds upon hundreds of dollars to get a perfect read out and even then always remember it‚Äôs only gonna be at the angle at which the camera is pointing at the time which sometimes in my case I need to get the DOT/MC numbers or the VIN registration numbers off of other trucks instead of just the tag of the trailer Which really doesn‚Äôt do much.  I will def check out the top performer here.    And just as a sidenote for anyone, that‚Äôs unfortunate enough to be in an incident where they have to use this footage just always remember when the incident happens immediately pull over as quickly as you can to a safe area and dial 911 because most law-enforcement agencies will not do much of anything if you decide to just go home capture the video and then call Police. They would rather the report be made out in the area of the incident that way it‚Äôs easier to verify everything even if you can‚Äôt get the video downloaded which in my case, I carry an iPhone card reader where I can pull it off of my iPhone pretty quick and at least give them little snippets of the video until I can get home to download the full video Which at 4K you‚Äôre usually going to have to upload to a Google Drive file and then just send them the link.

Why wasn't Vantrue N4 Pro added to this? It was highly rated, especially for having the Sony Starvis 2 sensor. And before you say "but other cameras here has the Starvis 2 sensor and they didn't perform well", well that's because they have shittier lenses and overall worse impementation of the sensor (shittier companies likely add this sensor to their shitty products as a marketing scam). I know it's pricier, but if you're going to buy a dashcam, you better get one that has the best image quality. After all, you're protecting an asset that's worth potentially thousands of dollars, and a lot of Americans would be SOL without a car (since we destroyed our public infrastructure and made everyone car dependent). I mean, if you're really poor and need just a front facing one, the Viofo is the obvious choice, but I'm sure people that watch your videos have vehicles running in the 10's to 100's of thousands of dollars, and there are better dashcams like the N4 Pro.   It's also still better to have the back camera, even if it's lower quality. They should have been tested just to show what the quality looks like.

TLDR; When choosing a dashcam, be mindful if you live in an area that gets very hot!  I'm very grateful I have a dashcam (Viofo 129 front and rear). I haven't had to use it personally but have been able to provide footage as witness to crashes (I even got subpoenaed for my footage on one). What I learned from this video and testing my cam after, reading plates is hard even with the best cam. If I'm in a crash, If possible to do so safely, I will try to position my truck so at fault drivers plate is close and in front, so I can point my cam directly at it, and hopefully camera has a second to get a clear pic, in case the driver decides to leave the scene. Maybe even shine a flashlight at it for a moment when I get out of my vehicle. My cam does pretty well when not moving, as long as plate has some light on it, but at highway speeds plates are just a blur.

Ditch all these cheap cams. Trust me, just pony up and get a Garmin. Best dash cam I've ever owned
While the testing in this video is very thorough, I do think there are some problems that either can't be addressed in a fair way or could have been done better. The clearest example is the position of the cameras on the windshield. Since most cameras are supposed to be positioned at the top of the windshield, its logical to line them up horizontally. However, this also presents issues, especially when most of the reference points are on the right side of the test vehicle. Since the brands were lined up left to right, it gave the cameras on the right side of the vehicle an advantage, even if it is a very minor one. Due to this, I feel it is a possibility some scores could have been different depending on position of the camera. Again though, it's a minor issue that seems very hard if not impossible to fully address.
The Viofo either has 1440 @ 60fps or 1440 @ 30PFS with HDR enables. It'd be nice to know the settings he used. If it's the same as what's on the screen it looks like HDR might be enabled @30 fps. Any chance you could comfirm that setting @projectfarm ?
I've had a couple of Viofo's and they work fairly well when new. About every 3 years though, it becomes impossible to get into the setup menu, so even though the speed is recorded accurately (with the GPS base), the date and time are off. Eventually you just have to get a new one. Also if you live in a hot sunny area, the plastic housing softens a bit and where it clips on and gets loose. Audible rattling. Dashcams are a must have IMO, for proof after a crash that it wasn't your fault - not so much for the cops, but for the insurance companies.

My wife was hit by a drunk/drugged driver at 9 at night coming home.  Her dash cam captured it all, a vehicle traveling in the same direction on the highway, swerving wildly across multiple lanes.  When it was 3 lanes over, my wife thought it was safe (dumb, I told her to always stay BEHIND impaired/crazy drivers) as soon as she's parallel with him he carenes over 3 lanes and perfectly pits her at 65 miles an hour.  Right into a cement barrier and then she was hit head on by another car 2 minutes later as she sat in the slow lane facing oncoming traffic.  All on dash cam video.  She lived.  She's actually fine now.  That being said, she could easily have been dead.  When she called me, that's exactly what she said, "I'm dead, I was in a car accident. there's blood.  I don't know where I am".    No camera, not hers that night, or any camera, is going to get a license plate in the dark.  Especially 100 feet back.  Keep that in mind.  They're good to have for insurance to prove no-fault, but that's about it.  No, they never caught the person that hit my wife.  There could have easily been a murderer walking free, and they probably wouldn't even know.  Sorry to ramble this out, but when I saw the intro scene, facing west into the sunset, I'm like oh, big letters in the daylight.  I studied my video for hours.  The worst part was, it looked like a dealer tag was on the car that hit us, so you've got that too.  I am in no way throwing fault at the testing here, Project Farm is looking at the best clarity for the money, I'm just pointing out what a dash cam can/cannot do reasonably.  We have the Wolf box G840S.

Be careful of amazon and other website algorithms... they give you insanely expensive stuff in early searches, but as you hold off on purchasing and continue to search for a few days or more, you will notice they will give you less and less expensive products.  I have also been told to not shop during business hours, as businesses will pay more for products so prices are higher during business hours and/or typical times of day when people will IMPULSE SHOP.

I've Viofo on my daily, never fail. On my weekend car, i've tried several other brand, nothing come close to Viofo reliability and quality. Now testing Ddpai on my wife car. Capacitor FTW
Reading license plates and signs is a big thing, BUT making it the only thing when comparing cameras is bad. There are a lot of manufacturers that have made it a priority and forced digital sharpening and more or less optimized it for the plates. If you then try to see anything else or just enjoy the scenery, it looks like sh*t.  Nowadays I look for electric lines, poles, trees etc. There will be cartoonish outlines and trees might look like there's snow on them when/where that's impossible. And it's really stupid. You can "enhance" the good looking picture if it needs that, but removing digital sharpening is pretty much impossible.  For few years, many dashcams have had some "intelligent" sharpening that looks like non existent content is hallucinated by an ai. Like a text sign that looks good, but is actually just gibberish.  They should at least have those "enhancements" as an option for the user and/or offer adding them when downloading the file from the camera.
Id buy the viofo if only it was usb c instead of mirco usb

dang, was hoping for a review of dash cams we would actually buy... this is all garbage. None the less, love your videos and all the effort you put into these
Dash cams have a problem. In order to get the best road coverage, they use wide angle lenses, which are poor for trying to get license plate numbers. And the only answer I have found is to do what the police departments have done, and installed dedicated telescopic cameras to record license plates.  It takes a special lens to allow the depth of field video needed to record near to far without having to focus the lens and drive. The way to do that is to open the aperture and let the camera AGC handle lighting conditions. A good video camera should have the ability to do fine, day and night with the right setup.  I have also found a rear video camera is important, especially with cops! When I get pulled over I ask what the problem is and they say whatever their story is, and I ask if I should check the video to verify, and they usually say, "Well watch your driving", and give a warning.  Only once did I still get a ticket, and I sent the check in with a copy of the video, and the check was returned with a note saying the ticket was voided.  Another thing, I use a 'rear view camera mirror' type of unit, and it gives me much better rear view, as I have dogs in the back seat that block the view, and the camera is mounted at the back window. It also has a backup feature that lowers the video, so you have better view of the ground as well! They also include GPS, which records location and speed data, which is why I ask if they want to review the camera...
Thanks for this. Based on this and other reviews, I ended up with a Viofo A229 Plus (not Pro).  It's not 4K, but it has front and rear STARVIS 2 Sensors.

I've had dash cams in my vehicles (business & personal) for years. In one instance, a reckless driver tried to stop right in front of me, probably to cause an accident to claim insurance as I was driving a well lettered company truck. Fortunately, nothing happened, but had there been a collision, the video evidence would have solidified my claim of innocence. In another instance, mine was the second vehicle in a four-vehicle collision. I was stopped behind a large SUV. Two vehicles behind me caused a "double-tap" to occur, slamming my mid-size SUV into the rear-end of the larger SUV. The responding office asked three separate times if I caused the wreck, was following too close, was distracted, etc. Each time, I stated that I was fully stopped. I finally showed him the video. After viewing it, he smiled, returned the camera, and stated that I had nothing to worry about (legally). The two drivers behind me were ticketed, fined, etc. I was cleared of any wrongdoing. A ~$150 investment that probably saved me hundreds, if not thousands, in legal fees, increased insurance premiums, etc. Dashcams ... don't leave home without one.

When a dash cam advertises "4K" video, it's important to understand that "4K" can refer to actual 4K resolution (3840x2160) or a lower resolution with interpolation, which artificially increases the pixel count to appear like 4K. Dash cams that use interpolation might not capture the same level of detail as a true 4K camera.    True 4K (Ultra HD): A true 4K dash cam records video at a resolution of 3840x2160 pixels, offering a high level of detail and sharpness.  Interpolated 4K: Some dash cams claim 4K resolution but achieve this by using a lower resolution sensor and then using software to artificially increase the pixel count, which can result in a less detailed image than a true 4K dash cam.

I'm more shocked at your gasoline price of $2.69, here in corrupt California we are paying $4.99.
Can definitely recommend Viofo.  I got an A139 after looking at Techmoan's review a few years ago and I've been really happy with it.  It's 4K (with a 1080p rear camera) and I used their hardwiring kit which records a 1440p 3fps video while you are parked.  With a fully charged car battery it records for about four days before cutting off (which still leaves enough power in the battery to start the engine without any problems).  While there are some compression artefacts in the video, it's still excellent quality.  The only drawback (which is common to most dash cameras) is that the dashboard reflects off the windscreen and causes a dashboard-shaped overlay to appear over the video depending on which way the sun is facing.  If the lens could be placed closer to the glass this would be less of an issue but I think it's difficult to avoid unless the camera goes on the outside of the vehicle.  I also had to buy a Sandisk "Industrial" SD card (as insisted on in the manual) because it gets so hot that normal SD cards shut down and stop saving video.  But once I switched to the industrial card there was no longer any issues with recording.  It has certainly sold  me on Viofo cameras as far as image quality is concerned.  They are more expensive than others but you do get a significantly better quality product for it.
Buy once, cry once.  Been using the VIOFO A129 Pro DUO 4K + 1080P rear;  Think of your dash cam as Insurance that you buy once and continue to use till it needs to be replaced.  The VIOFO's do have good quality and with any 4K camera, if it's wider angle, you NEED that 4K in order to get details, especially when the field of view is wide like 140 degrees, or more.  For some VIOFO models, there are circular polarizers that help with looking out of modern vehicles;  it also helps if your dash is shiny to get a DARK ( read this as BLACK ) carpeted dash cover to cut down on glare which also improves video quality .  I had a gray dash carpeted dash cover and well, might as well put a mirror on the dash or a big sheet of white paper ;  it reflects back poorly.  My point here is- it's NOT just the dash cam as you should also consider anything that can reflect INTO the dash cam as well, like your dash itself..    Been totally happy with the VIOFO as a dash camera.   Always get a wide field of view for the front and rear ; and never skimp out and get JUST a front facing dash cam;  Getting rear ended is a very common thing;  I think over the past 40 years, I've been rear ended like 8 or 9 times, hit from the side once,  and hit something in the front like twice, the last time being a deer.  I am considering replacing the entire system because, well, 2.5K rear mounted cameras are now available..   Road raging idiots are the #1 reason to have a dash cam nowadays, along with, the propensity to get rear ended by inattentive drivers.

Thank you for the information, as always! Project Farm has the best comparisons on the Web!  However, I find it odd that many of these dash cams performed MUCH worse than many published hobby projects, and ALL of these pale in comparison to basic IR cam projects .  48 hours of TRUE H265 or AV1 4K, DSP driven IR, and (basic 3x) Lidar range recording starts at about $160 worth of parts.  If you have access to PCBWay's shipping, then you can complete this project for under $200.  WAY better than anything pre-built, if you have fundamental electronics knowledge.  I only bring this up, because these prebuilt devices seems like a complete rip-off for the money.  Over half the devices you reviewed were figuratively useless as dash cams, and one would likely be better off with nothing instead.  Thanks for validating the community projects.   Just goes to show how far ahead the hobbyists/enthusiasts actually are, compared to the consumer industry.  üëç

Given the clarity I'd say it shows a clearly better sensor, but I'm no expert.

I use REDTIGER  Hasn‚Äôt let me down once
In a conversation with nerds, it came up that the way the video and audio are written to memory matter just as much as the camera's resolution.  Even if the camera is capable of 4K, and the file is technically in 4K, the hardware and/or software between camera and storage might cause things to be downscaled severely, so the camera's resolution claims need to be taken with a HUGE grain of salt.  That will also cause performance losses when there's more going on on screen, especially with lots of stuff moving.  We were actually talking about some bodycam footage we were watching, but it applies to dashcams.

Have a Viofo A129Plus that has a 1440 front and a 1080p rear camera and this is a 4 year old model. They offer several camera models. Higher resolution on the same size sensor makes the pixels smaller and that limits light collecting which shows the limitations at night. A 1080 or 1440 camera with the same size sensor will pull in more light per pixel than a 4K will and have a better night time image.

It's a shame you didn't do a temperature test. Living in the desert makes it difficult to choose a good dash cam. The 130+ degree weather inside the car is brutal, and most dashcam makers lie about their temperature ratings.

I have the Arifayz and the one thing I will give them credit for is their excellent customer service. Mine stopped working after a month and the responded to me within an hour to get it resolved
As a long time dash cam user I have learned something very important. I use NextBase. I started with the 322 (about $200) and was thinking of upgrading to the 522 so I did. A major factor to consider is how well do they handle the heat inside the car with the windows up during summer. When I upgraded to the 522 (about $300) the battery expanded inside the dash cam and pushed against the screen and caused a spot on the LCD. They can also put out a lot of heat so it would go into overheat protection mode and end up not running which would mean if someone hit your car while parked, you wouldn't have that footage captured. I went back down to the 322 for that reliability and safety of not having my car burned down due to the LiPo battery exploding.
I miss Apeman Dash Cams, but they went the way of Tacklife.

I thought I'd share a tip: A dashcam can also be used as a quick 'n easy security camera anyplace, anytime. It need not be chained to your car. Most only require 5V, so a 12V cigarette lighter outlet port is overkill. Connect a dashcam with a USB cable to a portable power bank to use as a nanny cam, pedo cam, burglar cam, body cam, etc. Report that neighbor. Catch your coworker stealing your lunch. I've been using the Viofo A119 Mini 2 for a couple years now. It has been great for capturing dash cam footage. Do yourself a favor and purchase the polarizing lens for the camera to help sharpen the image further when facing direct sunlight or high glare situations. Also buy a good quality SDXC card as a cheap one won't last with the constant write/delete that takes place on dash cam memory cards. This is the one I bought for mine.  SanDisk 256GB Ultra microSDXC UHS-I Memory Card with Adapter - Up to 150MB/s, C10, U1, Full HD, A1, MicroSD Card - SDSQUAC-256G-GN6MA

I HIGHLY recommend a dash cam. Sadly I believe they are all using outdated technology/ hardware and the main differences between them comes from the software and features. That being said I still highly recommend getting one. Personally I use a front and rear facing but if I did Uber/ Lyft it would definitely have a cabin facing feature too and I would turn on the audio recording feature. I have thankfully not yet needed the camera for my own proof/ witness of events but I have stopped and provided contact information for those involved in accidents that my cameras captured so they can reach out to get files. Hopefully that has helped them get a fair settlement/ prevent rates from going up because your insurance provider is only there to protect their bottom dollar. Taking care of you just happens to be a contractual obligation they will try to get out of every time for as minimal cost as possible.   Also, for whatever its worth I never use the GPS feature to watermark speed, I dont record my cabin audio and I wont release my footage unless I want to. All of that falls under the 5th amendment. (I'M NOT A LAWYER) I'm also pretty sure the only way I can be forced to release footage is by court order. Also, by design these cameras overwrite their data regularly so assuming my vehicle is still operational I have no obligation to preserve footage unless court ordered. Punch line is they better act fast if they want to force my hand. just whatever you do, dont go purposely deleting footage of an incident, that potentially is destroying evidence which absolutely is illegal.

What's happening here is that the sensor output is being upscaled. Upscaling is notorious for creating artifacts, which here creates the grainy resultant images. If they had used a proper sensor, the image would be a LOT more clear. Coupled to a random image processor, you're going to get exactly what you see here - varying capacities of clarity and light metering. Thanks for the video!

Its very important to mention if the camera uses a lithium battery or a capacitor as a power source, lithium batteries do not like temperature fluctuations. All cameras which are not quickly removable will die after a year or two of use if left in your car.  A capacitor is not affected by these fluctuations. My blackvue has been in my car since 2018 and still works like new because it uses a capacitor. It has withstood -30c winters and +30c summers.

Big question... how do they hold up in a hot car with direct sun beating down on them in a parked car. I had two dash cams fail in the summer heat. I have been using a Cobra for a couple years now. It's still working  fine.  The adhesive holding the rear camera has failed though, but gorilla tape helps.
I have the A129 Pro Duo and I like it a lot.  That is Viofo's 4K one  (one of their 4K models).  A quick note to those buying a camera, you don't need a 4K display to view the files!  No, they don't get cropped off if on a lower resolution display!  The TV or computer will just scale it down to fit the display and it does not look bad a at all.  You would just not realize that the clip was actually 4K resolution.  The only downside of 4K is it takes up more space but H.265 (HEVC) can be enabled as a more efficient video encoding method which will still leave you with good quality but smaller video files.  H.265 is supported by a lot of modern devices.  Many newer phones will play it back or play it back with your favorite video player app and there are good free ones like VLC (my favorite).

Viofo is awesome! I've been using them for the past 2 years, but i use a better version.  I use  VIOFO A139 PRO 2CH First 4K HDR Front and Rear Dashcam with the Newest Sony STARVIS 2 IMX678 Sensor. It's 1, 2 or 3 channel. The other 2 can be bought as package or separately later. Has lots of settings, 5G WiFi, GPS you go can control the frame rate and even parking recording has tons of options. I only run mine at 2K because it's still really sharp and that way it doesn't take up as much space on my SD card that way I have a longer record to go back if I need to see footage. Make files a lot quicker to download too because they can get quite large at 4K. 5 minutes intervals on 2k 60 frames is slightly over 1GB. You can also control the recording intervals like from 3 minutes to 10 minutes.

Tbh, I don't need video quality to be excellent. It just needs to show what vehicle did what, for insurance purposes. More important to me is the user interface, how reliable the device writes files to the SD card (one I bought last year seems to have an error booting up every 30 or so uses), and mounting hardware (ie. Cable length, the ability to remount to a different position). I know that's a bit difficult to measure quantitatively, but that's more important than video quality, as long as the low-light video quality isn't potato.

Maybe a 3d printer review?   There are plenty of YouTube channels, but maybe pick like 4 or 5 printers at $500 and $1000 (or close to those price points) and compare prints of various brackets and mounts (3 to 5 prints) using the default settings for those printers using 3 common filaments like PLA, ABS, PETG and maybe carbon fiber (swap out as desired or from community feedback). Measure the average room temperature over those prints (in case of poor heat retention from the enclosures), the amount of particulates in the air (especially for stuff like ABS), wear on the nozzle and or drive gears (estimation of common wear part life cycle), energy consumption (measuring efficiency of the hot end and heated bed), and maybe a subjective assessment of their software. Its less for a technical review of a printer and more of a practical use for people who primarily just download existing models for various projects (mounting brackets, car part fixes, furniture modifications, etc) and aren't really into doing their own design work and just need the printer to work as is. Would also be really fun to see some printers run off a generator!
you should also compare the $150+ dashcams. the high tear ones
On the tech side of it, Linus tech tips did a dashcam review a few years ago and discovered that almost all - if not all - dashcams use the exact same video processing chips which explains why there's so little difference in camera quality. The differences are almost all software side.  To me the dashcam market seems rather scamy. The products themselves are what they are but the marketing around them is all BS.

This test is proof "there is no free lunch", good image captures must be optimized to the specific lens & CMOS hardware & that coding time & testing costs money. Everyone buying on best specs for the money gets shit dashcam image captures. For those who don't know. The sensor, and especially the resolution of it, means nothing. It's the compression in the codec that matters. A dash cam will never give you good quality images, even at 1080p, because the videos would be huge, and bandwidth to the sd card and sd card size would quickly be a huge issue (think GoPro). We to this day watch movies in the theater at only 1080p
In your 2nd subjective sharpness test with the CoolCrazy and Red Tiger side by side, the Red Tiger is noticeably more sharp and clear but you stated the CoolCrazy was.  You can see all the holes in the sign pole with the Red Tiger, but only some with the CoolCrazy.

It takes months/years of Firmware updates to resolve issues or correct features that are printed on the box. Overall theyre still pretty cheap for the quality but yeah theyre not perfect

Lol Gemini tried to summarize   This video by Project Farm tests the performance of 11 different dash cams at various price points to see which performs the best. Here's what you can expect to see: Testing categories: License plate readability (0:10) Road sign readability while driving (7:46) Road sign readability at an intersection (10:17) Night vision performance (12:41) Light box sign readability (15:03) Key findings: Vio wins overall with an average finish of 1.3, offering excellent performance across all categories, especially night vision and readability of signs. (17:34) Red Tiger comes in second with an average finish of 2.2, offering solid performance in most categories. (17:46) Cool Crazy comes in third, (17:50) Other noteworthy mentions: Wolfbox performed well in many categories. (10:09, 14:18) The least expensive dash cams (v300 and Airace) struggled the most. (0:22, 1:06) The video concludes by recommending Vio as the best overall choice and Red Tiger as a strong runner-up.

Dashcams are such a well known thing now, yet it seems so hard to find a good one.  Thanks for the hard work on this one.  I've been a dashcam user for probably 13 years now.  I started with a cheap camera and soon found out why it was cheap.  Then my uncle found the Mobius Actioncam.  It's not specifically a dashcam, but it can be made to be one with settings changes.  It's only 1080p though, but my original camera has been running and swapped into several cars as I've changed cars over the years for at least the past 12 years.  I've bought two more for my other vehicles.  For a time I had a Blackvue camera.  It had a better quality image and a rear camera, but it cost significantly more and only used Blackvue SD cards, which were notoriously unreliable.  I had two fail before I abandoned the camera and kept using my Mobius.  I believe my original camera is still using my original SD card.  I've been kinda scared to try out any other camera because I can't imagine a more reliable camera than the Mobius, but I do want higher res images.  There's been twice in the last year I couldn't read plates with it.  My thing with the VIOFO is that it has a screen.  I want my camera to be stealthy so that if someone else were to be driving my car they wouldn't notice and unplug it (mainly mechanics).  The Mobius has done fairly well with that.  So I'm still on the hunt for that better camera.  I don't like all the extra features that just complicate the camera.  I just want it to turn on with the car, loop record, turn off with the car, be stealthy, and record a higher quality image.

I didnt see GARMIN
I sell CCTV gear and as you just saw in your review, the quality of the total package matters a lot more than the resolution of the image sensor. The glass, the CPU, and the firmware on the camera all have a huge impact on the video quality. I've had 720p cameras on my bench that can blow Harbor Freight 4k cameras out of the water in terms of video quality. The resolution of the image sensor is the least important part of a camera.

Anyone else find it odd that no dash cams are made by brands we've all heard of? Why don't Sony,  Samsung or Panasonic make any of these? Why are they all companies that sound like they were started last week and will be gone next week?
A year ago I was rammed head on by a driver who intentionally crossed into my lane then drove off. My car was totalled and the driver drove away, I don't know how, but he did.     My insurance denied my claim. No attorney would defend me because, despite spending the night in the hospital, I luckily sustained no serious injuries so there was no serious money in it for them. One so called "injury lawyer" flat out told me to fake an injury if I wanted any help.    I was accused of falsifying a claim because I had no proof to back up my statement.The responding officers had assured me that they didn't need to look for my assailant because they would be able to get his license plate number using footage from the traffic light camera at the intersection in which it occured. There was no camera and, despite numerous witnesses, no one wanted to get involved.     This was an extremely hard lesson; that dash cameras are a blessing, but also a curse. Insurance companies use them as leverage against us to deny any and, if possible all claims. I would suggest one for the front and another for the back. Good luck all.
Future Test Idea for PF: Ceramic brake parts lube vs silver (or copper) anti-seize vs. whatever else is out there for disc brake pins and slidey bits.  I'm reading everywhere that newbies are saying we were all wrong for using anti-seize on brake pins.  But back in the 1980's and 1990's ceramic, and other, brake lubes really didn't exist.  More-over, I'm from the Northeast where heavy salt was corroding brake parts, and wise mechanics used silver anti-seize to make the next service interval less of a hassle.  So it's not like it dried up as some people claim it does now.

Timestamps for each camera for future reference:  00:00 Intro 00:22 S/V300 01:07 Arifayz 01:42 Miden S7 02:09 E-Yeeger S60 02:40 Ovaman K600 03:17 Coolcrazy N8 03:51 Redtiger F7NP 04:35 Rove R2-4K (Dual) 05:21 Wolfbox i07 06:02 VIOFO A199 v3 06:45 PRUVEEO D90-4CH 07:20 Readability Results 07:40 Light Exposer Results 07:46 Street Sign Testing (All cameras) 10:07 Sharpness Results 10:18 Sunset Readability Testing (All cameras) 12:34 Sunset Results 12:43 Night Vision Testing (All cameras) 14:55 Night Vision Results 15:04 Night "Light-Box" & Digital Display (In-motion Bloom Testing - All cameras) 16:57 Light-Box Results 17:07 "Cheat-Sheet" reference of features (All cameras) 17:30 And the Winner Is... (Up to the needs of the buyer)    Personal Opinion: Looking at the side by sides offered by Project Farm, my ranking would mostly align with the provided results, with the exception of the ranking for Coolcrazy and Redtiger.  This being due to my own driving habits/driving conditions (I tend to drive at more absolute times (full daylight/full night) so the Coolcrazy would be ranked the higher of the two.  Given the limitations of testing in real world settings, this is an amazing compared usage in the wild, but the lack of controls on testing (i.e. he can't control the rotation or orbit of the world) the sunset testing may skew based on actual angle (and percentage of) the sun was visible at. i did a ton of research on this a few years ago. "which dash cam is the best" got a ton of videos and articles saying this camera is the best. then id see another video or article saying that camera was the best. finally went further down the rabbit hole and someone did a video saying they are all the same. why? because the camera inside is only capable of doing so much. its limited to its technology. so if you buy an expensive camera that " you get what you pay for" or a cheapo camera, its not going to offer much difference because the camera lens itself can only do so much. some features like night vision and stuff are the main differences but as far as camera performance goes you can only get so much no matter how much money you spend.

My suggestion is to get the fuse power kit no matter the dashcam. It gives you the ability to have the parking mode (assuming your dashcam supports it) on automatically without being overly draining on your car battery. You just need to find the right fuses to plug into. It is also pretty easy to route the cables up the A pillar in most vehicles and it will look cleaner instead of having the cables dangling to your cigarette lighter plug.  As an aside, I bought the Redtiger way before seeing this video. Glad to see I got a well rated dashcam.

6:02 I'm using the exact Viofo A119 V3 dashcam since Aug 2020 until today and never even heard of the other brands and models shown in this video. Another point not mentioned is, this dashcam uses capacitor instead of lithium battery, which means no battery bloating or replacement needed after a few years. Also bonus of using capacitor in dashcam; it is more resistant to hot sun exposure compared to lithium battery.  Pair this dashcam with the high endurance Sandisk dashcam/home security white SDCard without having it to die premature death for continuous recording.  This dashcam is the best bang for your buck for virtually any time of the day compared to other dashcams at this price point. Thanks for the Great Quality Review
Just a couple of things. While I appreciate the effort that you‚Äôve put in to the video, your testing methodology is flawed.   Stationary at X distance really doesn‚Äôt mean anything. Unless you‚Äôre reviewing parking mode.  Same with trying to capture a street sign on the side.   While dash cams do have wide FOV, they are designed to capture in clarity directly in front, at distances between 9-30ft. A camera that captures at 10ft not 30ft does not mean it‚Äôs a bad camera, but that‚Äôs what they have designed the lens to focus on, and the same in reverse.   HDR, STARVIS etc are also not night vision. They improve all lighting conditions.   (I work for a dash cam company)  Edit: just one last thing to add, resolution does not equate to a better quality recording. Resolution determines how much is captured, but the sensor defines the quality.
Thank you sir, you're the go to source of unbiased, backed up with testing, opinions of many a folk. Have a good one.

[9:06] Respectfully, I think you got it backwards here. The CoolCrazy's image is nowhere near as detailed and sharp as the RedTiger. The CoolCrazy looks like an oil painting, while you can make out individual blades of grass and even wood grain on the building in the background within the RedTiger's image. The tops of the letters on the streets sign are starting to blend together due to over-exposure and over-sharpening in the CoolCrazy's image, while the RedTiger has neither of those problems.

Good video, this was very well done, thanks.  In summary, While China does compete, very well, at the higher end, they also absolutely saturate the 'cheap, nasty, crap' market.
I have been using the same Viofo since 2019. Back then it was eating the competition, especially at night. It has never failed me even though it was exposed to numerous extreme temperatures between -20 to 60 degrees Celsius. It also never drained my car battery in the parking mode even during long periods of more than 1 month (I used both optional hardwire and standard lighter socket power supply). Above it all it has simple emergency function and doesnt require any app to fully configure the settings. I keep using it with the same old microSD, never causing any error whatsoever. The optional lens filter does its job and reduces the reflections in the windscreen. It also has a cool feature - when all the windows are fogging, Viofo heats the windscreen up a little so it is clear in front of the lens (I mean it's not a feature, the device is just a bit warmer and that's the reason). BUT My friend bought the same model a couple years later and his camera was having a microSD error sometimes. Despite trying a few cards and formatting them regularly it was occuring from time to time. It isn't necessarily the dashcam that was causing those issues, but it might be.  In the summary I recommend Viofo A119 V3 and would definitely buy again. All the optional accessories are worth it, even GPS helps keep the windscreen tidy by serving as a power source and mount at the same time.

I have a Viofo A119 Mini 2 (~$90 on black friday, I see it on Amazon now for $138) and it's working great in my Gen 6 Subaru Outback! It's just the front, but it's gonna be enough to cover you in most situations, and it's super clear and easy to use. IMO, the dashcam would lose a lot of value if you can't access the videos fast and easily, the Viofo's interface is very smooth and even if I have to wait a minute for the video to download, the wifi connection straight to your phone is a game changer.   for those with a Subaru, which often have eyesight sensors on top windshield, I fit my Viofo in between the two sensors and it doesn't interfere, the wire goes down to an internal cigarette 12V, but you can also hardwire it to the battery for 24H parking mode. Just sharing my experience, if you are debating dashcams please just get one in general! You're going to wish you had one when the time comes

I've got the A139 3CH (uses the better Starvis 2 sensor*) myself, and my gf the A119. These are great camera's. That said, if you don't have the money for a good camera, just get a cheap one. No matter how shitty your camera is, it still helps in almost all situations. Someone backs up into you and claims you hit them in the back? Even a horrible camera will show that this is not true. Other person drives into you while you have a green light, a horrible camera will still show you this.  If you have the money, get a good one, I would highly recommend Viofo. But if you don't, get a cheap one.  Oh and make sure to get a high endurance SD card. Videos keep rewriting the card, they will eventually break because of that. High endurance will last longer.   *While some camera's have a starvis 1 or 2 sensor here, they are absolutely shit. I don't know if they actually have those sensors, but if they do, their software is absolutely horrible. The A139 absolutely outperforms the A119.

I had the ThinkWare F70 for a few months and it has been good to me! However, I really suggest a second part with this particular model and other brands that might have a goofy name, like the Cool Krazy one and it performed very well‚Ä¶
The Viofo that you found was best uses a first gen Sony Starvis sensor. There are other cameras like the A119 Mini 2 around the same price from Viofo that use the Starvis 2 sensor. Those are significantly better. This video honestly doesn't test any of the actually good cameras on the market. The Starvis 2 sensors (IMX 678 for 4k and IMX 675 for 1440p) are well regarded as the best sensors in dashcams, and nothing else really comes close. The only reason the Rove didn't perform well is because it has poor processing, so it is wasting the sensor's potential.  Something like a Viofo A119 Mini 2 vs Viofo A229 Plus vs Vantrue E1 Pro vs Vantrue S1 Pro comparison would be nice. As far as I know Viofo and Vantrue are known to have the best image processing (Thinkware is good too but their good dashcams are expensive). Throw in the Rove R2-4K and maybe the 70mai A510/A810, then vs one or two popular dashcams without Starvis 2 sensors. Maybe throw in a Starvis (not 2nd gen) sensor dashcam in as well (like the A119 V3). If you have the budget, throw in a Thinkware U3000, Viofo A329, Vantrue N4 Pro and Vantrue E360 as the premium options.

The main to look for when buying a camera is to make sure it uses a supercapacitor as opposed to a lithium-ion battery. My first 2 cameras were lithium-ion battery and melted/expanded in the summer heat (in California and the midwest). Worth it to pay extra for a camera with a supercapacitor like the Viofo.

Yes thank you
Excellent video! I really like the way you think these things through. I'm a professional photographer and my life would be a lot easier if Nikon or Canon made a dashcam. I've been beating my head against the wall, trying to chose one. Every time I think I've made a decision, something new shows up.  One of the things that you showcased is the limited ability of digital cameras to capture a range of light. The range of dark to light that a camera can see used to be called "exposure latitude," but that isn't fancy enough in the digital world, so now it's called "dynamic range." The Viofo, RedTiger, and CoolCrazy cameras seemed to have the best dynamic range. They exhibited good shadow detail without losing highlights. That's pretty hard to do on an inexpensive sensor.  I like that you chose a backlit scenario, which is the toughest situation for an automatic camera. It is obvious that there is some sort of automatic exposure control going on in these cameras. There are three ways this can be done: Light sensitivity of the sensor, or ISO; shutter speed; and aperture, which is the size of the opening in the lens through which light passes. I am very interested to learn what method these cameras use. More sophisticated cameras can use all three.  The sensor's pixel count, in most situations, is not as important as the quality of the lens. A resolution of 1080p, which used to impress us, is more than sufficient for reading license plates and road signs; but it won't matter if the lens doesn't have the necessary sharpness.  In a case in which forensic examination is necessary, the video is usually paused. In that case a faster frame rate, or at least a faster shutter speed will render clearer details, but fast frame rates (which often require faster shutter speeds) lead to darker shadows.  There was a pretty broad range of white balance from one camera to the next as well. The poor old Miden was so warm it actually lost a little detail. I don't know the specs on those cameras, but I would almost bet that they all have fixed white balance. Once again, in legal situations, correct color balance can be important.  Thank you for this video, it has proven very helpful to me.
No garmin? I always get comments on good quality of image for garmin 57
You must have tested them all at once.  Same background movements.  How much is the SD card for the Viofo?  What capacity should be purchased?
I know there are hundreds of dash cam options out there. but maybe a round two including comparisons with action cams as well? Also, some brands like Sylvania offer dash cams as well available at part stores.

BEWARE: Do not rely on Viofo A119 to record an accident  Recently I drove way too fast over a speed bump and it really knocked my car around. Yeah I know, I should've paid more attention. But I learned something valuable about this dash cam that really disappointed me. The speed bump knocked my car around so much that I feel like it kind of simulated what an accident would be like, but to a lesser extreme. However, when I went back to look at the footage of my stupidity, the moment where I drove over the speed bump was missing from the SD card. So, while the car got knocked around a bit, that somehow prevented the dash cam from recording in that moment, or at least being able to save the file (and the one after it) successfully. I have the dash cam mounted with the sticky pad and it never fell down or got disconnected from power, yet it still failed to provide the footage AT THE MOST CRUCIAL TIME I WOULD'VE NEEDED IT, had it been a real car accident.  This might be a good dash cam to record a scenic drive, but don't rely on it to record when you need it most - proof for an accident that you may have. With the two missing videos, there was a 6 minute gap in recording on the SD card.  I was happy with this dash cam for the 18 months I used it, but after this mishap I realize I need to find a new one that won't fail when I need it the most.
Just wanted to note that if you want the top quality from the viofo but also want a rear camera, they have another model called the A129 which is compatible and comes with a rear camera. Obviously more pricey, but still cheaper than buying two A119s.

Average milliradians per pixel center field (mpp-cf) is the ONLY metric you should care about for reading plates.  "Megapixels" is an advertising gimmick that only *roughly* correlates with mpp-cf.  Both the angular field of view and pixel width determine this metric together.  Many dashcam shoppers get tricked into thinking that having *both* a large angular view and large megapixels is good, but the truth is that the two metrics actually work against each other.  This is why many expensive dashcams *still* can't read plates well.  My mobile phone is 4032 pixels and roughly 120 degrees view when held sideways.  That gives me (120 deg)*(pi  rad/180 deg) / 4032 pixel  = 0.00052 rad/pixel = 0.52 milliradian per pixel (average).  If I multiply this number by the distance to the plate, I get the corresponding size of a single pixel of a small area on the plate in a photo.  At a distance of 75 feet, I get (0.00052 radian/pixel)*75 feet = 0.039 feet = 0.47 inches per pixel, which corresponds to about 2 pixels per inch.  A skinny plate letter is about 1 inch wide.  You need roughly a *minimum* of 4 pixels per plate letter to read the letter,  so I cannot read plates with my phone camera at 75 feet.  So how close do I need to be for my mobile phone to read a plate?   The distance in feet = 1 / (0.00052 rad/pixel * 4 pixel/in) = 481 in = 40 feet.  That's just about correct for my phone when I test it.  Because you're *dividing* by milliradian per pixel, you can see that a smaller value for this metric gives a larger plate-reading distance.  Mpp-cf is the only metric that matters for reading plates.  It's a value that is hard-set by your camera's lens(es) and it's digital CCD chip.

I've been advocating for Viofo dashcams for about a decade now. They entered the dashcam market starting with a direct line of communication to their community. The early firmware revisions came many times a month as people would post their experiences with bugs and even suggestions. The developers were open to feedback and constantly improved the firmware and hardware. Most dashcams take some inspiration from what Viofo pioneered hand-in-hand with the community.   eg The preference of super-capacitors over lithium based batteries is a result of many user's reporting bad experiences with them bulging or exploding in hot cars - something developers didn't anticipate as temperatures didn't usually reach that high in their area. They knew cars could reach 150F in some places and on paper the batteries were rated for those temperatures, but over time the exposure would diminish that rating. Temperature swings are harsh on fragile electronics like dashcams. Other issues with early models included components melting or UV lens burn-in. The community reported all these issues to Viofo and all were addressed over time.

KNOW YOUR STATE LAWS! In several states it is illegal to record cabin audio without permission of the passengers.   This is best done by verbally announcing they are being recorded.   Without consent, recording individuals is still considered wiretapping by law.   Note:   Passing through a state with such laws still makes it required in that state.

All of these dashcams are of the "budget" variety and in my opinion none are worthy of purchase because their camera sensors are just too poor. It's also likely that each camera of a particular resolution is using the exact same sensor as the others at that resolution, with the only functional difference seen being in the image processing firmware that's employed. To get a truly usable dashcam that will provide the detail required to cover one's needs, I believe you need a minimum $250 investment with a Vantrue N4 dashcam being considered minimum spec.

I've been using VIOFO cameras in my cars for the last 6yrs. They're a bit pricey, but you get good performance and reliability.  One thing you should look into when buying a dashcam is the backup power type. Most of the time, you'll want one with a supercapacitor rather than a lithium battery. Supercapacitors are much more resistant to heat than lithium batteries, and your dashcam will be stuck to the windshield of your car where it can get baked by sunlight. The backup power is just for when power to the camera is cut (Such as when you turn off the car, or the car gets into an accident) and it only needs to last long enough for the camera to safely turn itself off (If it suddenly turns off unsafely, the last video it was recording could become corrupted).

The thing with resolution on cheap dash cams is in reality you (the manufacturer) can record at effectively whatever resolution you want, but if you use a low quality low mp sensor then it doesn't matter what the resolution is, it's going to look like crap. I mean you can upscale your 0.3mp flip phone cam from 2004 to 8k, but it's still going to be a blurry grainy mess.

For the viofo, you choose the "not so good version" if that brand; with the same sizes, but a better image sensor (a starvis 2) were the "Viofo A119 Mini 2" - it is really much better as the V3 (who is darker as the Mini 2), but had otherwise the same options - it just would cost a little bit more (~ 10-15$ more). also a neat thing for the viofo-cams: they can get a "CPL-filter", what makes them better, 'cause the windscreen - morroring the dashboard is then "away". they also had the opinion to get a "remote emergency button", where you can start a emergency image - even when you put one on the rear window, so that you can literally "operate" that one. and: they provide up to 512mb micro-sd cards - and they had against the "cheaper" ones another good thing: a "super capacitor", what is better than a rechargable battery - especially these will die after a time due to changing temperatures between 0¬∞ and 55¬∞C (32¬∞ - 131¬∞F) in summer and winter.  better as these, but also more expensive would be the A229 - that can also getting upgraded with several stuff (cpl-lens is then includes with the front camera) - a rear camera, a "indoor" - camera, a Telescopic camera for the front (what would be plugged in instead of the rear camera), the remote emergency button etc. - and it is atm the best performing one, even slightly better than the newer A329 (what costs way more than the A229). so, you can upgrade that camera with all that stuff even after have buyed a single one. on several occasions, like black friday and x-mas, there's also huge discounts on the cameras. jusr as information - there's 2 variants from the A229 out, a Plus and a Pro - and the Pro is the best (and expensivest) one.  before asking - i've had looked several tests of dashcams (moatly in german, 'cause of my country) - and had seen, that these mostly outperforming others... the only brand who can fight the Viofo's is Vantrue. that's also why i can provide these informations.

Something I discovered using a $6,000 camera for wildlife photography is that when I tried taking a shot of birds for instance through the windshield, the result is always terrible with very poor feather detail every time. It works ok for general shots of the land or road layout, but you are not going to get detailed shots with a camera by shooting through a windshield or even the windows in your house, it will always cause a certain amount of distortion.

Just FYI, the best performance for bright/night etc is decided by the quality and dynamic range of the sensor (the photo capturing surface). The higher the dynamic range, the better its ability to capture highlight and low light. Then software compression is the next factor. Thank you for all you do. Give yourself a raise. Really great testing!    Thank you!!!
I have the Rove R2. Doing great so far. One very cool thing is app functionality on the Rove. It's not essential to use the app but it's handy. The Rove R2 lets you instantly download clips in case you need to show police after an accident. I'm assuming the other cameras have apps, but I don't know for sure. Another cool thing is that the Rove R2 has a capacitor instead of a battery. This is helpful in hot climates as batteries don't do well in the extreme heat. Another cool thing about the Rove R2 is that you can invert the rear camera image with the app and set it as the main screen, effectively using it as a backup camera. The screen is tiny but it works for me. I've only had it for a year or so, so I don't know how long it will last. I also have another car with an unbranded rearview mirror camera. I prefer those since you can't tell from outside that there is a camera in the vehicle. And rearview mirror cameras usually have a touch screen and some of the more expensive ones have GPS navigation.

Excellent video. Jam packed with useful info and to the point. There is only one thing missing, and that applies to a lot of dashcam review videos. For people living in hot areas it is important to know if the dashcam is battery or capacitor-powered as capacitors are usually more heat proof and the dashcam will last longer. Its all the software. They are trying to squeeze the video signal to oblivion to get more out of SD cards. The Viofo and coolcrazy have the better compression and exposure algorithm. 1080p without being super compressed and analog camera would be more than sufficient. Until they use a better algorithm, they will all have grain and digital noise.
PSA, make sure to get an SD card designed for dash cams, a standard card will fail from getting overwritten so many times

Great video comparison. Helped quite a bit with my decision! Thanks.
Tech summary in a few lines. In a dashcam, what matter most is the SENSOR, much like your eyes. Viofo use Sony Starvis for the older models and Sony Starvis 2 for its models since 2023, both doing really well. CPU power is the next on the list. It processes the images and applies filters to them, like sharpening the numbers on the license plate. the last thing is the so call 4k/2k/1080p image quality, which means how much information is stored. If the sensor doesn't catch it, or the filters unable to fix it, saving a 4k video does nothing other than eating up your memory card faster. Other than this, you should know a higher sensor frequency allows you to catch images that move faster (in some cams you can set it - 4k 60Hz / 2k 120Hz), like a car plate coming from the opposite direction. CPL helps to not records your dashboard reflection. Park mode allows you to record while your engine is off. If you want park mode, you need to connect it to the 12V power which you need to pay someone to do it for you. If not it is possible to install it yourself. peace.
I'm surprised you didn't check the 70mai brand. They're the most popular in Europe and offer good quality at decent price. AFAIK, they're available in the US too.
This is very helpful. Many thanks
The only way to high quality video is:  Panasonic S1RII Leica L-mount 90mm F2,8 3TB harddrive 3x LED panels at 5000K Rodin gimbal 4x 12V LiPo for all day recording Stereo mike arrangement with sound deadening materials  If you can still fit in the cabin, you can safely record every second with perfect exposure.

You may have missed the fact that about 80% of 1080p cameras are actually "interpolated 720p" ie fake. They are 720p camera and the picture is upgrade ( each pixel is doubled ) so you get 1080p roughly. Also the Chinese like to add the rear camera (720p) and front camera (720p) together and the screen that displays them is 1080p. It's usually not possible to tell unless you take them apart. The main clue is the cheap price. If you want to see more details about interpolated fake dash cams, look at some of the videos on my channel. This fake interpolation can apply to 4k ones as well. This is a product/market FULL of fakes.
The Viofo also is one of the few that has no internal batteries (it uses capacitors) so if you‚Äôre somewhere where the inside of your truck gets to 150 degrees (like here in Texas) that‚Äôs a big plus.

One thing many reviewers forget to check or mention is what is the maximum size or capacity of SD card these cameras can work with. This will show you how often you have to replace the SD card on a long trip if you want to keep all the recordings or for the later editing. Viofo can be formatted to 256GB while many cameras can see only 32gb or 64gb. The older Viofo model 119 V2 could see 512GB formatted on your PC but V3 cannot. Only 256GB, but even this should be enough for all day driving. Also Viofo has an optional kit for ACC power connection for parking mode (HK3). It doesn't have any built in battery but uses a super capacitor so the camera is resistant to failure because of the high heat effect on batteries (exposure to the sun). I am not sponsored by Viofo, I am talking from my own experience.

I made a lower tech test like this about 6 years ago. I bought a few amazon specials ... ran them for a few days to figure out which was best. At the time I settled on ROVE products. I have them in 2 cars still running 6 years later. Easy to use interface real decent picture and most important ... no overheating. Back in the day overheating of the units was a big thing and powerloss operation. The ROVE had capacitors so it ran for approximately another 60 seconds upon power off and it would wake up upon impact which is a neat feature.

So glad you made this! I'd looked over other channel's reviews because you didn't have one yet, which surprised me. I learned that the reason such a vast majority of dash cams seem to have similarly poor or inconsistent quality is because most are using the same Sony sensor, from one major manufacturer, so the differences really lie in how much effort they put into the software. However, performance from the budget to premium range was not remotely consistent with pricing above the $120 range, and some $200-300 offerings were nowhere near some of the $100 ones. And, while I gained some knowledge in the process, without nearly as concise narration and editing, I just wasn't convinced that any of them were worth it. I figured there had to be something out there that wasn't complete garbage and wouldn't break the bank, but the performance of the seemingly premium options was definitely disheartening. That was a few weeks ago, so when I saw the title of this video I instantly saved it, then watched it... at 4am lol The one thing I would say that puzzled me on this one was at 9:09, when you gave the edge on sharpness to the CoolCrazy over the RedTiger! The RedTiger looked just as good or better than any of them on that shot to me. And the Hue, Contrast and Exposure were leaps over the CoolCrazy in that lighting, just like the previous shot with the distance markers, both of which looked a bit overexposed to me. But, that shot in particular probably blew me away more than any other comparison, because the previous ones had been so bad and the CoolCrazy and the few before were starting to look better but, having watched other videos without zoomed clarity comparisons and lack luster performance from pretty much all of then, I just didn't expect such a drastic difference among the top performers and such a well balanced image in that lighting. In the end, your overall rankings were spot on and with the best side by side footage on YT to back it up, in addition to the standard no frills, lean and mean narration that no one else can hold a candle to, so THANK YOU, again! Dash cam user here. There is another very important parameter. How easy to remove and hide the camera. My was stolen one day. So I like those cams with some kind of quick release. It is better if they have power in the mount like redtiger does. Magnetic mounts are great too. Another thing to consider is the battery. They wear very quickly so camera can corrupt last clip. Some of those dash cams using super capacitors instead of batteries. It is better because those are not wearing.

Note about the image quality if anyone's having trouble reading some of the shots: a couple cams that were said to be readable were not readable at all for me, but I bet that's due to YouTube's video compression. For instance, at 4:27 I absolutely cannot read the COOLCRAZY at 25 feet, and it's due to the kind of smearing that could be caused by video compression.  I've seen this happen before with videogame image quality comparisons on YouTube- sometimes the presenter points out a clear and visible artifact, other times it's the sort of artifacting that video compression turns into a general smear.

Thanks for this Todd.  As always - exceptional!    I have been playing with some sort of crappy ones that I've gotten from Ali Express in the $10 to $20 range. I never expect much.  I order them mostly to denounce them in ratings based on over inflated video quality and other parameters and then once refunded, I take them apart to see what's in there.    A big one used to be that if it has a Mini USB socket, well then, it's going to be pathetic, that USB standard by todays standards is pretty archaic.  Not always though these days.  I then went on a body cam thing and out of maybe fifteen that I got, I think four of them were half way decent but needing a power bank to make reasonable recordings.  Resolution seems to always be over inflated.  They upscale low resolutions in bigger packages to say it's 1080 or what have you but video qualities are always a question mark.  2K - Yea, right.  LOL    It looks like a few of those cameras you reviewed look pretty good.  The other thing is Infra Red in night vision scenarios.  Many wavelengths don't transmit well through glass but a few do.  A test there would be to use a phone camera (which usually picks that up) viewing from the outside of the windshield to the camera inside, you'd see white dots from the IR LEDs.  On the other hand, some sensors are really great in low light conditions and may offer good images without IR.  It's interesting stuff for sure.  You did some Very interesting tests!    Again.  Thank you.

The annoying thing about dash cameras is the technology to read licence plates exists, but virtually zero manufacturers for everyday consumers make telefocal lenses. They make them for police license plate readers and consumer only get wide angle lenses.

So what enables a clearer image/video is the bit rate, the frames per second, and most importantly the Hz. Resolution doesn't really matter you can get great results if all the the numbers for the above technologies I mentioned were high with 1080p you could get a beautiful picture, of course 4K is desirable.

I highly recommend everyone get themselves a dashcam. It can save your butt if you are involved in an accident that was not your fault. Don't let the other party know that you have a dashcam until they have talked to the police. Then you can show the officer what REALLY happened. Lawyers agree that for most cases it's best to get a dashcam WITHOUT a GPS since your speed could be used against you. Take your time installing it (or have a car audio place install it for you). Get one with a capacitor instead of a battery: They have far greater resistance to heat and loss of capacity over time. There are single, dual and triple camera dashcams. I recommend a dual set up in case you get rear-ended. The 3 camera dashcams are mostly of use to Lyft and Uber drivers since the third camera is an interior looking one.

I bought the i07 Wolfbox and the review is spot on but it doesn't have Sony Starvis 2,  I don't think it's even Starvis 1. Like a lot of the dashcam claiming they're 4k, Wolfbox is not real 4k but interpolated 4k, you're better off choosing 2.5k since the quality is about the same as 4k with a smaller file size.   I ended up returning the wolfbox and the reason was a failed GPS after almost a month of use. They sent me a replacement resulting in the same failed GPS. From what I can diagnose, the problem is their manufacturing decision to place the GPS on the part that mounts onto the glass which in time, after days in the scorching Las Vegas sun, warps the plastic creating a gap, thus the GPS part no longer in contact with the main body connectors.

Great test suite, especially the 35 MPH pass-by.  On dashcam footage I've seen, they faire poorly when there's a hit and run. Regardless of which camera (front or rear) or time of day, legibly reading the license plate or seeing the driver's face, almost NEVER happens. While the 4k cameras seem more promising, and a ~$114 price is appealing, they still fall a bit short. I'd pay a premium for one which 'ups the game' - 4k+ front and rear, 60 Hz+ frame rate front and rear, on 2 (preferably more ) cameras, and smarter image processing algorithms.  Offering 3 or 4 cameras would permit narrowing the field of view - innately improving the resolution  A gold standard baseline might be a 'GoPro', set at 4k, with 60 (or 120 Hz) frame rate.

the problem of all these cameras is lack of dynamic range which important at night.  most of them make the license plate unreadable and blown out because they're trying to raise the exposure for the car and background.  if you lower exposure for the license plate to make it readable, the background and car become too dark.  it's a balancing act that most cameras fail at.  even expensive cameras find it challenging to expose for both the license plate and the background/car.

This review was top-notch, on a very difficult subject for consumers: too many offers, too many almost scammy products. I did not like the Coolcrazy because it is using a reconstructive mini-AI filter to get sharper results, but when the signal is too noisy, it puts up a high contrast image but with unrecognizable gliphs. You can see that very clearly at the stop sign with the yellow sign below. I wouldn't get that camera. The other two cameras on top of the CoolCrazy are the real deal: compensating the difficult light condition wth good optics and fast adaptation of capture parameters, and traditional HDR capturing, just like with any conventional camera, no funny business.

There are many things to like about Viofo's cameras apart from the image quality. The use of capacitors instead of batteries helps it survive being baked in the sun for years, and the parking recording function is one of the better implementations I've seen.  PS: Dashcams use the battery/capacitor just to finish writing to the SD card when you turn off the engine, not to power the camera the whole time when the car is parked. For parking recording, you generally need to wire the camera to the car battery or some other power supply.
