Thanks for reviewing these!
the best sensor in the world really isn't that useful without enough processing power behind it to make use of the sensor. i'd really appreciate a round 2 where you compare the more expensive, and physically larger units to see if they offer even better visibility and image processing.  - recording looping is also pretty important, since you don't need to constantly go through and clear out the card to make space. it'd be nice to know which cameras actually loop recordings.  - ease of use and navigation for configuring, although subjective, would be a nice thing to know as well. when some dash cams only offer 2-3 buttons to navigate with, it can be difficult to use.  - information about the attachment point, including area, the kind of adhesive included (if included), and weight that would be suspended from that attachment point are also important to know, because heavier units will require a larger mounting area to be secured. - another good test would be to see how difficult it is to cause the cameras to change their position. whether the camera itself pivots, or the unit pivots at the attachment point, vibrations and jostling will eventually cause them to move. while this may not necessarily be important for day to day use, it could be important for off-road driving, or driving through construction zones where uneven roads can cause significant turbulence. just having an idea of when to check the alignment can go a long way. - having an internal battery to record while the car is parked can be especially useful when travelling. even so, not all cameras use the 'parking mode' the same. some will only activate when the vehicle is disturbed, while others will activate when they see motion. this can be a make or break detail for some buyers, especially those who will often park in parking structures.  - lastly, you should test their ability to see without the headlights on while at night, to see how good they are at detecting things like people walking up to the car, or reading license plates of vehicles that drive by the car. this is particularly useful in aiding others that may have been victims of various crimes.  I know that's a lot of extra testing, and that asking for you to test more expensive units means more costs, so if you can't do any of these things, that's totally understandable. either way, thank you for what you do, and how you do it. the world is a better place for it, and we all appreciate it.

Good job covering those cameras against your criteria. Those are all very poor cameras - I would not select any of them. A lot of your testing demonstrates something all of photographers know- most all cameras have the highest quality sweet spot in their center of the lens > center of the photo. As you examine images captured away from the center, the image quality falls away. So those gas road signs, up-and-away, even when illuminated, are a tough job for a camera that hopes to have fps, center quality, but suitable quality in the periphery. Hey, best way to insure you can get the license plates..., get a higher quality dash cam for overall, make sure to buy quality the batt. & Memory card can handle heat, esp. if 4k !! but buy a 2nd cam, like a portable, wearable bullet cam, so you wear the high quality and it looks everywhere you turn your head. I use on my motorcycle and it's excellent - you gotta lota money !!

One thing that wasn‚Äôt in the test but I believe is very important is whether the dash cams have BATTERIES, or are driven by a super CAPACITOR system. The Viofo has a capacitor, so you don‚Äôt need to worry about a battery expanding and failing after being in the hot sun for a year. I‚Äôve had a few with batteries and will never own one again. I personally have had the Viofo for a few years now with zero problems. It is highly rated on dash cam forums
For anyone curious I actually purchased a viofo a few years ago when linus tech tips did a breakdown video and im extremely happy with it. VERY IMPORTANT >> get a micro sd that's rated for endurance. Most dash cams will keep writing over old footage and if you don't have a card that's meant to handle all the re writes you might find yourself in trouble. Samsung makes an endurance card meant specifically for dash cams etc and has been absolutely amazing!

One thing to note is that the Viofo achieves its sharpness by having an angle of view of only 140 degrees while many of the other cams have a field of view of 170 degrees.  Not saying that's a dealbreaker, but something to keep in mind when choosing a product which has a primary purpose of documenting events of as large an area as possible.

You gotta be careful when a product lists some crazy resolution like 4k for stuff like this. Sure, the actual resolution may (or may not) be whats stated, but the bigger player in that game is the sensor size of the camera,. It doesn't really matter if the camera is "4k" if the sensor itself is only the size of a pin head, that much compression (as shown in some of these cameras) makes it pretty much unusable

a major feature that needs testing is if the cameras use an internal battery to finish powering off when power is cutout OR they use a capacitor.  Basically, any dashcam using internal battery will fail as the heat and cold weather will kill the battery life.  Capacitors however, have been surviving the brutal Houston weather.

The short answer is buy a Viofo. Yes, they're more expensive, but they're worth it. Better all around performance day and night than anything else on the market. And that's what you buy a camera for: to be able to positively identify someone who hit you. If you can't read their plates, the camera is useless.  They will also last longer because they use a capacitor instead of a rechargeable battery.  We all know rechargeables lose performance the more you use them. They die even faster when subjected to extreme heat and cold like in a car parked outside. Capacitors are unaffected by temperature or frequency of use.

I feel _almost_ disappointed with this review. Not for its _lack_ of thoroughness ‚Äî the content meets previously-established standards for this channel, nothing out of the ordinary, but my concern stems from not testing known-compatible configurations using a generic single-board computer like the Raspberry Pi 4. It would had been the most expensive solution, requiring a few 3D prints and some dinking around in Raspbian (its own recommended Debian GNU / Linux) so I understand its exclusion.  If there is a sequel for cameras attached to an SBC, Raspbian might be what Raspberry Pi Foundation _expects_ most people to use with their hardware, but DietPi is also _very often_ a specific-purpose lightweight ARM Debian system which may have high circulation due to some guides on this platform using it, as well.

One more cam that you should look at, though it stretches the budget some more (they have gone on sale and dipped into your price range), is the Cansonic Ultra Dash Z3+. It's been discovered that the ability to reliably capture license plates isn't so much about the resolution of the camera or even the frame rate, but its lenses' ability to reach out and get a good look. The Ultra Dash Z3 and Z3+ have a wide angle lens *and* a telephoto lens. The wide angle captures a much broader image like your standard dash cam, but the telephoto gives excellent, very visible focus on license plates (honestly I think you could have a cam with just a telephoto and it would be fine, but it is focused further down the road and will probably miss close up incidents.  If you want to see some great reviews with demonstrations of this, take a look at Vortex Radar's channel.
The inexpensive Viofo is the only real dashcam in the test.  The rest are junk.  I understand you buy all your own items for testing, and Good dashcams' are very expensive.  Image quality is just the tip of the iceberg.  Do any of these have parking mode?  Which ones have GPS Speed and location? Which ones record sound?  Which have adjustable impact / glass break detection? Can any of these notify your phone if your car is hit while parked?  Any fool can buy a $50 dollar dash cam and most fools do.  A more valuable test would be of dash cams starting at $200 and up.  Cars and trucks are very expensive - good quality dash cams are too.

I notice you're using the marketing dimensions at 17:12 but 2.5K is the same as 1440p. 2560x1440. At some point, the marketing switched from counting the vertical pixels to counting the horizontal ones. 1080p (1920x1080) is sometimes referred to as 2K.

Sadly, the Viofo you tested (A119) has been on the market for NINE YEARS. The 3rd revision of the A119 costs $61.99 on Amazon.  The completely redesigned A119 Mini 2, which was released 2 years ago, costs $115 on Amazon, and is far superior camera to the outdated model you tested.
If you want a Viofo with front and rear, the A129 (1440p front, 1080p rear) is not much more than the A119 tested.  For just under $200 you can get the A229 Plus (1440p front and rear).  For just under $300 you can get the A229 Pro Duo (4k front, 1440 rear). This one has some problems running if it's too hot (e.g. after being in a car parked in the sun). So you may want to opt for the A229 Plus instead if you live in the south or desert regions.

You didn't review it, but I went with a Fitcamx for my dash cam last year.  What's unique about them is that they provide a factory install by replacing an existing windshield cowl and tapping into the existing wiring harness that powers the rear view mirror.  This makes the install seamless with no need to route power.  I guess the caveat is that you need a somewhat newer car.

Dashcam mounting tip: Some dashcams ship with a transparent plastic sheet. You mount that on your windshield, then mount the dashcam on the plastic. That makes it possible to easily and cleanly remove the dashcam from the windshield if you need to change its placement. Re-mounting is a little trickier, but in general this is much better than mounting directly onto the windshield.  What if your dashcan doesn't come with this plastic sheet? If you've got extra PET screen protectors for an old phone, it's the same thing. You may need to trim down its size with scissors (try to round the corners). But it'll work just fine - just trim the sheet about 3/4 inch bigger than the edges of the mount. Mount the side that's supposed to go on the phone face to your windshield, then attach the dashcam adhesive to the other side (remember to remove any peel-off plastic - use sticky tape to lift the edge so you can peel it off).  If you only use glass or TPU screen protectors, there are a ton of PET screen protectors for old phone models available online for like $2 for 3-10 sheets. Don't bother buying one from the dashcam manufacturer for $15 for 1-2 sheets. It's literally the same thing. I recommend getting ones for bigger phones so you can use the extra sheets for applying other things to your windshield - like parking decals, toll road passes, etc.
Voice is over the top

Yes!, PF came into my feed with another cool review üòé
There are so many variables concerning DC's, that it can be overwhelming. One aspect that is critical is GPS. GPS is a critical factor in noting day and time, estimating speed, exact positioning for things like stop sign violations, etc and having that proof recorded in a single file through the camera implies a greater degree of legitimacy as opposed to a phone GPS. Before purchasing one, check the statutes for whatever State you live in, many State's have ordinances limiting the way that DC''s can be mounted, and consequently used without receiving a vision violation just for having the camera mounted incorrectly. Being able to read a license plate from a distance is important, but being able to prove you weren't speeding or did not commit a stop sign violation is more relevant. Great breakdown.

Perfect review this guy is the best!
Which camera has the widest field of view?
A lot of "4k" dashcams use a 1080p or 1440p sensor. It then upscales the image to 4k and writes that to the memory card. Which is pointless since the underlying resolution is not there. All it's doing is running hotter due to the extra processing needed (becomes important when running on a hot day after being parked in the sun), and wasting space on the memory card. Do your research before you buy, and find out the sensor the dashcam uses and its resolution.  The newer Sony STARVIS sensors have an augmented night mode which captures a still frame from a license plate (generally brighter since they're designed to reflect) before it's overexposed, and overlay that on top of the rest of the image which needs a longer exposure. Not every manufacturer has correctly figured out how to use this mode. Without it, license plates at night can be unreadable because they're either overexposed into white nothingness, or too blurry due to motion blur. For this case, I recommend searching for recent dashcam video reviews of the model you're interested in. As many youtubers do extensive tests and post actual video footage samples.  Edit: And if you're curious, I use a Viofo.
Honestly wish there was a good system to just use my iPhone as a dash cam. It would probably easily outperform all of these cameras while also being a decent substitute for Apple CarPlay.

Amazing work comparing. I remember watching a dashcam overview maybe 2 years ago, don't remember by who, which effectively said that there's only a couple of sensors being used in the industry, so most of the difference in cameras is how they process the image. I suspect that's visible in comparisons you made where there's some clear artifacting when processing high contrast/colour-change areas. Incredibly helpful assessment, so thanks.

Having some experience with a few of these I know that they don't always default to the highest quality settings and, like our old CRT TVs, do require some tuning and fiddling with to get the best quality picture.  A few of these were shown to be so truly terrible that I have to wonder if a protective film on a lens got overlooked (I've seen some have two films, a larger one that covers the whole lens assembly/cone, and another applied carefully, directly to the glass of the lens with just a tiny pull tab for removal) and seriously made me question what settings/adjustments were made using the menu options. The #1 thing you need to know when buying a dashcam is whether it has a supercapcitor or a battery.  If it's got a battery, it'll simply stop powering on after 2 years.  You should check the capacity too, to see if you'll get half a second or 10 seconds of recording after losing power from your car (e.g. key switched off).  Unfortunate that this isn't even mentioned in the video.  But to be fair, the better, more expensive brands usually do this correctly as well.

Seems like just a cheap $100 point and shoot camera would outperform all of these.
Viofo is probably the best of the Chinese-designed budget bunch, they seem to mostly win all these comparisons for image quality, either outright or bang-for-the-buck.  Korean companies (Blackvue, Thinkware, Finevu, etc), generally offer a more refined camera in terms of software and features like better implementation of parking mode and cloud support, but at 2-3X the cost the value proposition isn't there for most.  Buy something with a Starvis 2 image sensor.  Get a capacitor model, a 140-150F windshield isn't nice to batteries.  And I'll go ahead and fill out my dash cam complaint card with this: resolution is the big selling point, but IMO it's overrated for the dash cam use case, and the power required to process 4k video can potentially run too hot for the camera (even Viofo has had issues with that).  What's needed are better optics, an additional channel with a cheap fixed telephoto lens like every phone has had for years, which would ace the "license plate test" for even 1080 cameras.  There are a scant few that offer that option, and last I heard Viofo's add-on lens works by replacing your rear channel which is a joke. This is simply a niche market lacking in innovation and design for the most part, and I doubt there's a Samsung, Sony, or Apple coming any time soon to raise the bar for the industry.

I picked up the Viofo A229 a little over a year ago now, which does include a rear dashcam as well. They've held up very well, parking mode is great, and visibility is awesome! A little pricy but not too bad, considering how helpful they can be.
One feature I feel that is important as well is the power.  Many of these cameras can use batteries in parking mode and the choice of battery can be a concern.  NiMh is a good choice, but Lithium is not.  The best choice is a capacitor which is not as affected by heat and cold and can add more life to the camera.

Six months back I bought a Rove R2 dash cam. Generally, I'm satisfied with the product. However, there's a couple of things I'd love to see an improvement upon. The back screen picture can be rotated 180 degrees, but the on-screen labels' orientation cannot be altered. Another issue with this camera is more significant. When I stop the vehicle, say, for a traffic red light, and the engine stops running, the camera keeps recording. Once the engine kicks back on, the camera completely shuts, the back screen goes dark, and it take a few seconds to restart. Whatever events happening during that time in front of the camera, get lost. It would be interesting to know how the reviewed cameras handle similar situations. Thank you for sharing.

Things to remember about dash camera:  1. Their main benefit is producing evidence for insurance and legal matters and as such turn off any features they may harm you such as GPS (speed) and microphone (distracted driving). 2. They are a two edged sword they can help and well as harm you. Using these should help improve your driving habits especially when you watch some of your stupid mistakes. 3. They are an insurance policy and like insurance, it will hopefully never get used but when it is needed, it is indispensable. So add a few bucks to get quality. 4 Check them regularly to make sure they are working and the time stamp is correct.

I'm glad you did this, but camera quality past reading license plates is probably the LEAST useful thing for a dashcam. Testing the collision detection and if rollover recording works properly is far more important. As well as if it "breaks" videos into sections and if they have any pauses between those. I've tried a bunch of different ones where rollover recording just doesn't work and you have to manually wipe it every couple of days, or the "segmenting" of videos leaves me with 10-15 seconds between segments of unrecorded time, which is absolutely horrible.   I'm not worried about a hit and run getting away as much just making sure the damn thing actually records properly.

IMPORTANT: Yes, the Viofo A119 V3 is a pretty good cam for the money, but anyone living in a hot climate should be aware that the included base gets warped and becomes loose after a few months in 100+ degree heat. I had two of these cameras start to produce barely usable footage because the camera was rattling all over the place even when fully slid into its GPS mount.  The A119 mini 2, A129 and A2XX series all have much better windshield mounts. The A129 Pro I have in my daily driver has been perfect after 4 very hot summers in Arizona. By contrast, my replacement mount holding my A119 V3 in my second car is already getting noticeably looser after a few months being parked in the sun, and the brutal heat is still around the corner.

Depending on which state you live in, to be able to use the dash cam in court it must have an accurate GPS as well as specific parameters, like acceleration, speed etc.  The video itself may require certain timestamp in for example.  Essentially this is all to prevent the video being tampered with.

I have had several Rove units. They last about 2 years and the GPS finally can no longer recognize the new satellites. They also get flaky in operation and the clock functions are horrible. Thank you for another great evaluation.
I did similar tests with a hand full of dash cams and came to the same conclusion about viofo. It's sad that no one seems to make anything even better than viofo for people willing to pay more for better equipment.
I've had good luck with the VanTrue E3 (and N4) dashcams. One thing to note, many of them will use the same Sony sensor, so it's really just about packaging, support, and price.   A few tips for those in the market:  - If you live in a hot environment, make sure you get one with a super capacitor (Thinkware, VanTrue, etc.) as they do get hit from sunlight + the interior of the car = dead li-ion. - If you want 360deg coverage, consider going for 2x cameras with front+rear, mount one front to the windshield, one to the rear window, and mount the rears to the side windows (one each side). I did 2x with front+interior+rear, and so I have the added forward and backward looking interior (6x cams). It's *way* cheaper than buying a proper 4-5ch unit. - Spend on the Samsung Pro Endurance or SanDisk Extreme mSD's built for dashcams (both of these go on sale a lot). I was going through microSD's pretty rapidly before I switched. Go bigger if it's not much more $$, as that'll give you more mSD cell-wear protection in the card. I've been using 256Gb, since they were cheap.  I already had them pay off. I got in a fender bender a few months back, no damage. I was able to show on the cam the other driver's damage was preexisting (she slammed on the brakes) and we both agreed no harm no foul.
This video made me even happier with my purchase of a VIOFO! This channel is awesome!

It doesn't need to be the highest quality.

Some of these dashcam are a total waste of money.  Especially those that still feature 1080p. And some of these are old school.  They're not the latest.
None of those cameras actually went into night vision mode, because in night vision mode, the image would be black and white.  You were really testing their colour ability in low light.  If you take the cameras out onto a dark road where they have to go into night vision mode, don't expect the 4k cameras to perform better than the 1080p camera, because almost all 4k camera use a feature called "pixel binning" to effectively combine the output of 4 adjacent sensor pixel into a single pixel. This means that in night vision mode a 4k camera has the same resolution as a 1080p camera (i.e 1920x1080)
Can you test Spray Foam Tire Shine?

You should note if the dashcams have optional extras for sale like CPL filters(reduces glare) and the hardware kit to enable parking mode(detecting movement while the car is off). These features absolutely shows which companies are more invested into making better dash cams. Also you should do a super capacitor line up of dash cams. These are especially important in states where hot weather is common. There are very few lithium powered dashcams like the A119 models from VIOFO that can survive the intense heat. Perhaps simulate a hot car interior with a heating lamp as well.

I installed a dual (front and rear) dash cam about 3 months ago, we were rear-ended about a week ago.  What a major difference having video makes. A 20 min call with Gieco, upload of the video with the app and our claim was fast tracked. No statements swaps with the insurance companies, no delays. It might be important to know that 2.5k and 4k are marketing terms. 4K is actually 3840 pixel (horizontal resolution). The defacto standard name for this resolution is UHD (Ultra High Res.) in consumer electronics. 2.5K is close enough to 2560 pixels.   One important spec for video clarity is the capture rate. It might be 10, 15, 30, or 60 frames per second. The difference is significant. I guess you could check it with a video capture program like VLC.
-What you should have included as a test was how easy it was to use the instructions.  I have the Viofo A114 in this video, but I replaced it with a VanTrue OnDash N4 because the VanTrue has much better video, but also the Viofo was difficult at best to figure out!  The instructions were written in Chinese and then they literally used an online translator and the result was vague and difficult.  The VanTrue instructions leave a bit to be desired, but there is much more information.  The VanTrue was $250, way more than the cams in this video, but I installed it in my '14 Cayman S and put the Viofo in my 2001 Subaru Outback LL Bean airport car.

I have a Viofo A129 Pro, it fits the bill at all levels.... Maybe a little lack of features (would love a Wifi Station Mode, but it's kinda rare on dashcams without donating a kidney, they had it in a beta firmware but disappeared, seems they're afraid the heat generated by recording+wifi at the same time is too much) and Viofo sorta listens to the community on some forums, not something that happens that often (albeit they don't implement or fix everything, but it does happen, and there's often help when needed) they also have a few accessories, like the permanent/accessory power harness to avoid draining your battery and have parking mode, and the little bluetooth button to lock files (useful, ppl drive bad in southern france)... I went with a Viofo Front &Rear Pro, and opted for parking-lot recording, last spring with the upgraded image sensors- it's been great so far.  The imagine quality during motion and also during nighttime are equally as important as just having a 4K sensor. And in some cases as shown in this review you don't need a 4K sensor and are going to have to compromise 4K vs 2K60FPS. Make sure to read up on and view how well the actual quality actually is- don't just follow the manufacturer product info.   Probably would have been worth measuring the surface temperature after 30-60 minutes of recording at medium to high quality recording- these do get warm to the touch- combined temperature in 85+ can't be a good thing for any of these cameras or the memory card!

The Wi-Fi transfer is slow so I'll take the card out every so often for file dumps, but all the immediate features you'd want (e.g. mute mic, permanent save, switch display view) are right on the front panel buttons. It also has a gps module so you can include an overlay of your speed on each clip if you want. The thing has been recording almost non stop ever since I installed it, and can record up to 1080p 60fps with ten minute or less clips that get overwritten when the card is full. I bought it after maybe an hour of research and I'm glad I did.
I used the Viofo for years, but wanted a rear camera also so switched to the Redtiger. I haven‚Äôt been disappointed and it works well for my needs. Redtiger also has very responsive customer support. I have a set in two cars and both work well.

Just about any dash cam is better than no dash cam at all. My first $50 dash cam saved my butt in a parking lot fender-bender ($1000 damage). The guy that hit me actually got two security guards to lie for him and say they witnessed the accident. They all worked for Intel in Chandler, AZ where the accident occurred.  My second dash cam, a ROAV A1, helped me get over $80,000 total between totaling my truck and an injury settlement my lawyer was able to negotiate.  I'm now using a Thinkware U3000 2 channel which costs somewhere under $400. I haven't tested it as completely as what is done in this video, but the quality of the image seems lacking. Hard for me to say as I don't even own a 4K display. There's one video I tried to get a license plate off of and it was unreadable to me, but Google Lens was able to read it. The one thing that I can say is that the Thinkware software is pretty good. The phone app works well, and the transfer rates are decent. Some of my previous dash cams had terrible connections to the phone app, and had abysmally slow transfer rates, if the transfer didn't fail every time.  I would actually go so far as to say that the software matters more than the image quality. If you can't even get a video off of the camera without pulling teeth then the image quality will be your last concern. Also, in the several accidents I've been involved in the other person's license plate didn't matter at all. What mattered most was being able to prove the accident was not my fault, and even the grainiest image can prove that with or without a license plate. You can look at my channel to see a handful of the dash cam videos I have uploaded. I have tried to identify the dash cam model in the description of most of the newer videos.
I see you agree with Linus Tech Tips with the Viofo being one of the top choices in dash cams and overall price. It all depends on the sensor. A lot of your dash cam brands have just about the same sensor with the exception of a few brands that use the Sony Starvis sensor. Also, the lens size. Most dashcams have a small lens, and if the lens is bigger, then it lets in more light for the sensor, wouldn't be as grainy as most of the ones tested. I was surprised you didn't test the Blackvue, Rexing, Cobra, and Garmin brands. It would probably be a close comparison to the Viofo brand.

I love your testing and channel, but this one is absolute BS. Just 10 minutes more sunset can make a HUGE difference on image quality of the same camera. So unless you have a controlled lighting environment, this test is 100% flawed. The sensors on the dash cameras are around 8.5mm in size. A sensor that tiny struggles in low light conditions. Compared to a full frame camera that has a 35mm sensor. With a tiny sensor like that, every couple of minutes of sunset has a noticeable impact on the quality!

I'm surprised VanTru didn't make the cut.  I used to use VanTru's dual dash cam years ago for rideshare driving.  I switched to RedTiger about a year ago, only because I was tired of having to pull my SD card to watch the footage on a computer.    The RedTiger dash cam has an app that lets you connect to the dashcam via a wifi connection to watch and download the footage.  I was happy with that camera, until a recent accident where I was backing out of a parking space, I stopped, and then a Tesla backed into me.  The dashcam footage was cut off and all that was seen was when our cars were sandwich together.  I could not figure out why for a while why the footage was cut off.    The problem with the RedTiger dash cam (and probably others), is that it does not have an internal battery.  So when you first start up your car, the camera doesn't kick on right away because it has to go through a boot process.  If you are a person who starts up your car and takes off right away, you can get hit (just as I did) and the camera not catch it, because it didn't fully boot up.  That is about the only problem I've found with the RedTiger dash cams.  On another note, RedTiger has very superior customer service and they are always willing to go above and beyond to address any issues.
Ive bought viofo a119 vw like half a year ago because it seems like the best budget dashcam, like not one of thise 500+ bucks cameras offer much improved performance overthis

Love your reviews but: You only looked at performance. When you own a dash cam, there are nay functional issues that are critically important. If you want to get an image while driving, how is it triggered and what does it remember and how long. How easy is it to use the user interface? Can you easily and without a magic memory recall how to use the hing? Can you see anything on its tiny screen. How easy is it to get recorded segments. Does it drain your battery? without a magic memory. Can you talk to it? Is it easy to use if its been 1 year since you read the manual? HOW EASY IS IT TO USE! If you can't use it, the performance is BS.

I haven't pulled the trigger on buying a dashcam because of all the mixed reviews so it was nice to see you put this together.  I know what I am buying now.
Nice work.  I don't have experience with dashcams, but I do have experience selling digital camera equipment (albeit, 30 years ago).  Even back then, there were big differences.  While I'm sure much has changed (in terms of technology and of course pricing), the basics are likely the same.  To get an image, you can't just go by the marketing on the box.  There are many parts at play here, that work together to provide a quality image.  The lens, the pickup sensor, the processor and software to put it all together.  Now, it's likely you'll see cheap stuff finish low and more expensive ones finish better, since it is most likely that the more expensive brands have put better pickup sensors, lenses and processors in their cameras.  Where this can go south is if one brand wants to put a "4K sensor", but still uses low end lenses and processors that result in a mediocre result despite being "4K" (for example).

I have an old Waylens Secure360 4G. Already been through one accident and many hot days with no issues with shutting down due to overheating. The heatsink on it is the best I've seen. The most common issues reported across all dashcams nowadays are that they all use the same sensors, and they all tend to overheat even on mildly hot days.

I shopped around and just ended up buying another Redtiger, as they seemed the best option.  $110 every couple of years isn't too bad for the peace of mind. Perfect timing. Thank you.
I have tried out many dashcams for many years. Viofo has been the best imho. It has better image quality no matter day or night than many more expensive dashcams. HOWEVER, it can overheat in summer time when parked under the sun for an extended period of time. You would have to unplug the USB and plug it back in to restart. Sometimes you might not realize it has shut off because the red light stay on when it's overheated. So it can trick you thinking it's working. I would suggest everytime when you get in the car in summer time, press the button on the Viofo. If it responds to you, then it's fine. If it doesn't, restart it. If you wonder which models of Viofo I had tried. I have tried every one of them except A129 (which is the front and rear cam combo)   One thing PF should have tested was heat tolerance on the dashcams and maybe the adhesive / suction cup on the mount as well.  Most of dashcams will fail (image quality) and Viofo is no exception, but it degrades less. Some adhesive / suction cups will fail under direct sunlight.  But I highly recommend getting a dashcam with all the dishonest drivers out there. Protect yourself from insurance fraud. Don't wait till you get in an accident then wish you have one. Because that's too late, you had your chance.  I hope this helps!

got 2 older (A118C +A119V2) viofos and they are still performing good. Better get the GPS version, thus the clock will be always spot on. Note to anyone using a dash cam:  Make damn sure your date AND time are accurate!  In the event of an accident (your fault or not), the other parties insurance company will try to make the video footage inadmissible if they're not correct. And if that footage is what's about to save you... that would be "bad".

Digital cams are so good these days, it‚Äôs so bizarre that no big name company has put out a quality dashcam. I‚Äôve shopped off and on for one. And usually give up with the endless never heard of brands with lots of vague bs marketing.  Your review here is so needed to wade through the sea of options. Thank you. It‚Äôs clear which brand makes the best images.
Most of these cameras are inexpensive web cams in various bodies. What separates them is the processing and exposure programs. In low light situations a camera will up the ISO, which makes the exposure better but at the cost of resolution. Better processing can ease the effect, but that processing power comes at a price. The exposure programs can also make a huge difference. For instance, the camera can expose for the brightest object in the frame or it can expose for the average amount of incoming light. The best exposure programs will adjust for the situation but I suspect that these are fixed, and finding balance can be tricky, which is why a lot of them struggled with the gas station sign. The lens on the camera can also affect the quality. While I doubt any of these came with high-end lenses, there are better and worse options for lenses and there are also various coatings that can help with things like glare.   Many of these tests are torture tests, which is absolutely within the idiom of this channel! And these cameras will largely look just fine in full daylight.   Thanks for all your hard work!
If you do this again it would be interesting to also see things like a GoPro or insta360 camera that have loop recording. Whatever the oldest one is that supports it, you could probably pick up used would probably be around the same price as some of these and would be interesting to see the image quality comparison.

Thanks for the great review. I want to finally confirm my suspicion about Wolfbox and Viofo.  The reason I went with Wolfbox is because they offer a Mirror Dash Cam. It's much more convenient to use a mirror style dash cam than a regular one. I can see behind me with a wide view that allows me to see my blind spot.  Over the last 5 years, I have used three different Wolfbox mirror dash cams on three of my cars and I like them all. My latest one is a G840s with an updated backup cam that allows me to see better at night without the glare from the car's headlight behind me.  If Viofo ever offered a mirror model, I would switch but it would cost like 2 or 3 times more.  For people that do not own any dash cam, you should get one, even at the mid-quality in this list. It will save you a lot of headaches when you actually get an accident. It saved me twice  already, my insurance just needed the video clip and determined that I was not at fault.

I had a Voifo A119S similar to what PF tested here. After several months its power connections began to fail and eventually rendered it useless. It‚Äôs now relegated to my junk drawer.  It has been a common problem with Voifo, & all the cleaning and rubbing in the world of electrical contacts as suggested by Voifo does absolutely nothing to fix a poor design.  There are 4 spring loaded tiny pins that need to make contact in the mount, and this is where the problem lies.  Even though it might produce a nice picture, it won‚Äôt fix a terrible design. I wasted good money on it and I‚Äôd advise avoiding this brand as they did nothing to fix the problem.  Never again.

Dash cams are an absolute must. My wife and I have been in four driving incidents and in all four cases we were completely exonerated for having any fault and in all four cases the other parties insurance paid 100% of the damage to our vehicles all because of the video. In one incident (road rage by the other party) having the audio and front and rear cameras proved our case in a civil proceeding that was more than just damage to our car. Rear cameras can help with context in an incident so I wouldn't own a car without them. Just a couple of weeks ago we provided our front and rear camera footage in a hit-and-run that my wife and our cameras witnessed. We had a BlackVue 900X in one incident and a Vantrue 3 and 4 channel in the others. All provided sufficient resolution for driver and license plate identification although all incidents were during the day.

That $22 dash cam saved my ass in a wreck. An old man pulled out in front of me while I had the right of way, causing me to rear-end him. Thank you for doing these tests.   It really goes to show that--just like in digital still and video cameras--image resolution isn't the be all end all in determining which model is "best".    Some of those 4K offerings have heavy image compression and/or struggle with high dynamic scenes (bright sun and shadows or bright sign at night).   I suspect some of those lower end models are likely upscaling a lower resolution to 4K.   ¬†It's also interesting to see the differences in digital sharpening and noise reduction that was applied across all those models you tested.   Some were more aggressive in their application than others.      I ended up going with an Alpine dual camera model that's a rebranded Thinkware and it is 1080p in front and 720p in back.     One thing that's difficult to test for is how reliable and durable these dash cam systems are.    They get very hot under use and depending on where you live in the world, will bake in the sun all day.    Extreme heat is not electronics' best friend.    Lastly, I'm of the mind that having any dash cam is better than none at all.
Dashcams seem to have had no advancement in quality in the last 15 years

Linus Tech Tips have a video a few years ago explain why most dashcams have poor results. They all use the same sensor in their dashcams. There weren't many options to be chosen, but Viofo uses the newer gen of the sensor. Thus gives the best result compared to the others.

Half way through the video now, just to add, Viofo also do a lens filter that improves the image and also to help with exposure, set the camera pointing down so that road ahead is just above the middle of the frame so it's used for exposure readings rather than the sky.  Finally, you are using an older (3+ years) Viofo with the older Starvis chip the newer cameras use the Starvis 2 which is much better.

Resolution for detail, frame rate for reading signs at 30 mph, Low Lux for night, (A single candle light is 10 Lux, there are cameras that have Color picture at 0.0005 Lux), WDR (wide dynamic range) for making detail out of backlit scene, HLC (high light compensation) for bright lights shining into camera lens.

I have used the VIOFO for near 13 years and have no regrets, the best part of the VIOFO is they use a super capacitor and not a battery, and when you live in hot areas, a battery will die in less than 1 season.
I have 2 VIOFO front facing cameras. Installed one in the front and one in the rear. Don‚Äôt bother with getting the DUO set up. Picture quality isn‚Äôt as good in my opinion. I‚Äôve had my cameras for 5 years now without issue.
Great review as always. I've owned a few different dash cams and came across VIOFO a couple of years ago. I put the A139 Pro in both of my vehicles and have been very happy with them. Twice now, I've been involved in collisions and the dash cam footage has been very helpful. Insurance companies love it because the video is an independent third party witness. People are generally very unreliable when it comes to providing eye-witness testimony to police or insurance companies. 10 people can see the same event and have 10 different versions of what happened. The video shows what actually happened. I especially like having both front and rear facing cameras, as well as parking mode which many dash cams have now. In today's world, you have to have video evidence in order to protect yourself from scammers and liars.
Decent hdr makes a massive difference in low light performance along with a good sensor. I purchased a viofo a119 v2 in 2018 at Techmoan's suggestion, it still performs very well years later. I should test and see if it's worth getting the newer model or not. The competition seems rather lacking.

Buy once, cry once. I used 3 or 4 other brands of dash cams and they were all terrible and didn't last in Texas heat. The viofo a129 duo has been the best investment by far.
I use Nextbase cameras in our vehicles. Expensive, but clear 4K, and the app has telemetry data. Not only GPS speed but X and Y axis G force as well. I've had three of them so far. Full disclosure, they were all sent to me for free to review. However, I've been sent other brands to review as well, and I haven't found any other brands that match their quality.   Regardless, even a cheap $20 dashcam is better than nothing! My first dashcam was a $20 no-name from Amazon. A girl came across my front bumper and basically did the PIT maneuver on herself. Her insurance claimed I came into her lane. I asked for an email to send the dashcam footage. They immediately accepted fault and asked what body shop I wanted to use. Even with somewhat subpar quality, it was clearly visible that I never moved from the center of my lane and she came across me. Invest in one, even if it's only a cheap one.

I've had the Viofo A129 (same as what Todd tested, but dual channel) in my wife and I's cars. I'm not surprised it won. It's a great dash cam.
My 5 year old Viofo front and rear camera has worked great for years. I would suggest it to anyone, however if you want one wait for Christmas sales. Last year they were half off. I would also suggest the previous model if price is the issue. If you have a problem with another car read their plate out loud in case the camera has difficulty your sound will record the plate. Also if you have a newer vehicle that has the battery saver function and cuts all power a few minutes after you stop your engine you'd need a battery pack to use parking mode. Battery packs are more expensive than most dashcams so be warned.

If you pull 100 dash cams apart you'll find only six camera sensors  makes and models between all of them.  But even then if you compare all of the dash cameras that use the highest quality best sensor you'll still have a lot of difference between the devices when reviewing the footage. Finding a dash cam with a good sensor is only half the battle. The board that the cameras plugged into and the disc it's being saved to etc etc matter just as much as the sensor taking the picture.
For anyone new to dashcams, Viofo has been the standard for years.  Don't overthink it, just make sure to get something because most people will lie after a collision occurs...and don't tell them you have a camera.  Models with a capacitor are hardier than ones with a battery.
